And brain stimulation is more than just a new way to treat mental disorders.
As NPR's Jon Hamilton reports, it provides a way to actually probe tiny areas of the brain to find out what they do.
Pictures of the human brain can tell you a lot.
But Alvaro Pascual Leone of Harvard Medical School says pictures alone aren't enough.

The only way we are able to really disentangle the functions of this very complicated organ is by tapping here or there and being able to find out not just what the consequences are, but perhaps even more intriguing, how the rest of the brain is coping with that disruption.
Transcranial magnetic stimulation gives researchers two different ways to tap on parts of the brain.
One is by using an electromagnetic frequency that temporarily disables brain cells.
Eric Wassermann runs a brain stimulation unit at the National Institutes of Health.
He says researchers there suspected they had found an area of the brain that was essential to speech.
But they didn't know for sure until they used stimulation on volunteers to disable that part of the brain.
Wassermann says that by using a different frequency, electromagnetic stimulation can also make brain cells work better.
